While [recently] surfing the Internet, I came across a news story where Mariano Rivera, relief pitcher for the New York Yankees, had just finalized a deal to extend his contract with the team for three more years for a whopping $45 million.
 
 In light of the recent allegations of rampant steroid use by nearly 100 players in and around Major League baseball, I find it quite disturbing.
 
 First of all, does Mariano Rivera think he's so good that he really deserves $45 million? I, along with a lot of other good hard-working people, will never see a small fraction of that in a lifetime of work, and they don't even work 12 straight months a year. 
 
 Secondly, steroid use is a form of cheating, an unfair advantage [over] those athletes who've never taken steroids. Hank Aaron hit 755 home runs without the benefit of steroids and other performance-enhancing drugs, and 755 home runs was a Major League record that stood until Barry Bonds recently broke it.
 
 I say that Barry Bonds probably would not have been able to break Hank Aaron's home run record if he wasn't taking steroids, but worse than that, he lied under oath in a court of law about taking steroids.
 
 I was really disappointed to find out that Mac Maguire was on the infamous list, because I really thought he was a class act.
 
 Are we going to continue to patronize and glorify these losers? Let them take steroids or kill dogs in illegal dogfights, or let some millionairess bimbo try to get out of serving a DUI jail sentence?
 
 To glorify and find it acceptable to take the easy road? Probably so, we have no sense of honor, duty or integrity anymore, and we're all guilty of it.

Celebrity worship is a strong religion, not just in the United States Sports Machine, but all over. Pele was an astounding soccer player and for a while was the highest paid athlete in the world. (I watched him score from midfield during a '60s game here in Atlanta.)
 
 Champions get respect and high pay regardless of their off camera activities. Their attitudes seem to gravitate toward "I'm untouchable", "I'm special", "I'm bigger than the rule book" or some similar undeserved pass regarding personal behavior.
 
 We brought the high salaries on ourselves. Their activities follow bell shaped curves...exagerated by the huge piles of money at their feet.
 
 I haven't paid for a baseball ticket since the strike that killed the WS. If the owners would get together and drop their salary caps to where all the players made good salaries with no instant millionaires created every season, we'd have more and better athletes...and the price of tickets might become reasonable to those who can't afford hundreds to take the family to a ball game.
 
 The price of superbowl TV ads tells how much we value our sports...too much!
